caption: Harry Potter" creator J.K. Rowling revealed that lead film actor Daniel Radcliffe is Chinese.

result.explanation: The image shows Daniel Radcliffe.  The caption's claim that J.K. Rowling revealed he is Chinese is incorrect.  There is no visual evidence supporting this claim. The image only shows Daniel Radcliffe, and his ethnicity is not visually apparent.

candidates.title: 'Harry Potter' Author JK Rowling Reveals Daniel Radcliffe Is Chinese?
candidates.content:
Claim:
"Harry Potter" creator J.K. Rowling revealed that lead film actor Daniel Radcliffe is Chinese.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 6 January 2017, the satirical web site ClickHole, an offshoot of The Onion created to mock clickbait and viral content, posted a story reporting that the author and creator of the widely popular Harry Potter series had revealed that Daniel Radcliffe, the actor who portrayed the boy wizard in film versions of her books, is not English but Chinese:
Ever since releasing the final book in her beloved series, J.K. Rowling has been known to reveal some shocking secrets from inside the Potter universe. Whether its a characters hidden past, a plot point we may have missed, or a look inside what our favorite witches and wizards are doing today, Rowling has proven time and time again that theres still plenty we dont know about the magical world of Hogwarts. But the authors latest bombshell really takes the cake: J.K. Rowling just announced that Daniel Radcliffe is Chinese.
Whoa. Mind = blown!
As proof, the web site included a series of fake tweets by Rowling, allegedly made on 6 January 2017:
The tweets don't appear on the author's authentic Twitter timeline, and according to available biographical information, Radcliffe was born in London, and neither of his parents is of Chinese descent.
ClickHole, like its sister site The Onion, is an openly satirical web site. Here's how ClickHole describes their content on the site's "About us" page:
Lets be honest: Today, the average website carelessly churns out hundreds of pieces of pandering, misleading content, most of which tragically fall short of going viral.
At ClickHole, we refuse to stand for this. We strive to make sure that all of our content panders to and misleads our readers just enough to make it go viral. You see, we dont think anything on the internet should ever have to settle for mere tens of thousands of pageviews. We believe that each and every article  whether about pop culture, politics, internet trends, or social justice  should be clicked on and shared by hundreds of millions of internet users before they can even comprehend what they just read.
ClickHole has one and only one core belief: All web content deserves to go viral.
Some of the headlines on ClickHole's front page as of 6 January 2017 included "Passing The Torch: Watch This Father Give His Daughter His Panini Before Walking Into the Forest Forever" and "One Day I Will Understand Basketball (by Jack Nicholson)."
candidates.description: The claim that J.K. Rowling said "Harry Potter" actor Daniel Radcliffe is of Chinese heritage originated with the satirical web site ClickHole.

result.explanation: The news caption is directly contradicted by Source 1 from Snopes.  Snopes explicitly states that the claim originated from a satirical website, ClickHole, and is false.  Snopes provides evidence that Radcliffe was born in London and has no Chinese heritage. The claim is debunked.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly labels the claim as false and traces its origin to a satirical website.  It also points out the lack of evidence for Radcliffe's Chinese heritage.

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external validation checks strongly indicate that the original caption is out of context. The internal check, with a confidence score of 7, points out that the image shows Daniel Radcliffe, but the caption's claim about J.K. Rowling revealing him to be Chinese is factually incorrect and lacks visual support.  The image itself offers no indication of Radcliffe's ethnicity.  More significantly, the external check achieves a confidence score of 10, relying on a reputable source, Snopes, which definitively debunks the claim. Snopes traces the false claim to a satirical website, ClickHole, and provides evidence confirming Radcliffe's British origin and absence of Chinese heritage.  There is no conflict between the internal and external checks; they both agree that the caption is false. The high confidence score of 10 is primarily driven by the external validation's strong evidence from a reliable fact-checking source. The internal assessment serves as corroborating evidence, confirming the lack of visual or contextual support for the claim within the image itself.  In summary, overwhelming evidence from both internal analysis and external fact-checking sources points conclusively to the caption being entirely fabricated and out of context with the provided image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation processes strongly concur that the caption is false and out of context. The external validation, supported by a reliable fact-check from Snopes, provides definitive evidence contradicting the caption's claim. The internal analysis supports this conclusion by highlighting the lack of visual or contextual evidence in the image.
